title: Could Donald Trump go to jail? - Quora
tags: Presidents of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Original Question: Could Donald Trump go to jail?  He could. Let us start by making an observation. Many people are assuming not only that Donald Trump is a criminal, but that Mueller has the evidence that would convict him. No matter how likely that seems, we still do not know that to be the case. Secondly, there is also the possibility that Trump could resign in exchange for a Pence pardon. That is risky for Pence and the Republicans. I am not saying it is impossible, but they remember 1976. The “X” or unknown factor is what the Trump base might do if Pence does not pardon Trump if Trump resigns. Would they accept it? Or would they turn on the Republican establishment, including Pence? I lean toward the idea that the Trump base would turn on the Republicans, which would be more disastrous than pardoning Trump. Even losing the 2020 Presidential election because Pence pardoned Trump would be less bad than having the MAGites turn on the Republican Party. Pence and the Republicans would of course, have to amp up their rhetoric about the Democrats being controlled by the “Deep State.” They could probably do this. And the Republicans will still have gerrymandered districts until the 2022 election. But a Pence pardon of Trump would definitely turn independents against the Republicans. All of this presumes, of course, that Trump is willing to resign in exchange for a pardon. Would he actually accept that deal? I think so, but I am not certain. If he does not, and barring the Democrats nominating an idiot, Trump is going to lose in 2020. And if he leaves office unpardoned, he will face prosecution. One fair bet is that he will refuse to resign until after the 2020 election, and then only if he loses. The question in that case will be whether pardoning Trump would hold any value for the Republicans. Each day that passes, the value of a Trump resignation declines slightly. It is an imperceptible decline right at the moment, but after the New Year it speeds up, because if he is going to resign, Republicans need time to get their 2020 campaigns going. Pence cannot assume the nomination is his. If Trump resigns, whoever the Republican nominee is in 2020 is going to have win over the Trump base. So, assuming Mueller has the evidence that would convict Trump, Trump’s only way to avoid jail would be to resign and receive a Pence pardon. Pence himself might be in trouble too. So that is a bit sketchy at the moment. Pence may have personal motives for not wanting to pardon Trump. Like say, keeping his own freedom. So it is very possible that Trump could see the inside of a jail cell.

The history of American Presidents getting impeached is - scanty. There have been exactly two Presidents who have been called in front of the Senate to answer for their actions. Both were acquitted of wrongdoing. That being said, there is reason to believe that Richard Nixon would have been the first President who would have been found guilty and probably removed from office and indicted - had he not stepped down and been pardoned by Ford. Trump may or may not be impeached. It is too early to tell and the GOP, who control both Houses of Congress are currently watching with extreme caution the ensuing allegations being brought by Mueller and his team. Note, Mueller didn’t attach his first allegations to any wrongdoing directly by Trump at this time. However, there are indications that Papadopoulos has admitted that he personally tried to collude with the Russians by meeting with two individuals - one of whom he believed was Putin’s niece. Trump can scream that he had nothing to do with Papadopoulos - however, he is on tape saying that he thought that Papadopoulos is a great guy and there’s a picture of the two of them together. In many people’s minds, there are dots connecting. Now, on the one area that can give Donald Trump coverage is his base - as far as I can tell the GOP base is still behind him - eroding, but strong enough that the GOP leadership is interested in harnessing that popularity to get their agenda through the legislative process. As long as they perceive that he can turn his base against them - to their detriment, so they lose their Congressional seats, they will back him. However, his constant feuds with his own Party - not to mention the fact that some in the GOP leadership are looking at losing their seats any way, may end up meaning that they will feel no loyalty to someone who has no loyalty to them. Last but not least, if the House turns over in 2018 all bets are off. If the Congress flips, the Democrats will be salivating at the prospect of serving the Articles of Impeachment to the Senate. A disenchanted Senate may feel that taking their chances with Pence may be better at getting their agenda passed, and will cut Trump loose. If Trump is the first President to be removed from office - and he doesn’t make a deal with Pence to be pardoned, he may in fact be indicted.

Anyone could go to jail. But, in the US, the person needs to be charged with a crime, properly represented, a court decision is made (which can be appealed) and then “if” found guilty a sentence will be imposed. It is not likely that an actual prison sentence would be imposed for a minor infringement such as campaign finance violation (not reporting a contribution after the election as supposed to). It’s actually common and there is no precedent of charges resulting in any prison sentencing. There is possibly a small fine for the paperwork omission. The other armchair grabbers such as considering building in Moscow (But later deciding against it) or paying off an extortionist you once had an affair with to keep a lid on it, or saying crude things are not illegal. There is no viable way to charge someone because their adversaries believe (or want to make others believe) they might have done something, but they just can’t find or figure out what exactly it was. For those wanting a perp walk and severe prison sentence, this may not be a popular answer. But, it is grounded. It’s not suspenseful, won’t get me ratings or viewers every night waiting for more heightened suspense, all intended to have the popcorn flowing while everyone waits for the grand finale. Sorry folks, unless there is some real crime found, there isn’t going to be a harsh sentence because of the need to fill a void and make the ending good. This is reality, and if you were a President, and had the same minor infraction (if that) it would work that way for you too!

Will Trump go to jail? Almost certainly not, at least not while he is in office. The Talented Mister Trump may or may not be indicted, which would be problematic, but not impossible for a sitting president. Meanwhile, he will almost certainly be impeached after the midterm elections in November 2018, and it is more likely than not that he will resign or be removed from office. What makes all of this problematic is the fact that Trump has a loyal following of about 1/3 of the voting public. However, 2/3 of the voting public are not at all loyal to Trump, nor is the voting public going to be the final arbiter of these decisions. Rather, the 116th Congress will play a central role, as will the Supreme Court, along with the Justice Department and various State Attorneys General. The bar for indicting a sitting president is high, but the legal opinion asserting that it can't be done doesn't really say that. Even if it did, a legal opinion is not the same as a Supreme Court Opinion. The argument that a president plays such a critical role in government could easily fail by virtue of the fact that we have a vice president, whose job it is to fill in for a president when a president is incapacitated. Moreover, the prosecution of a president could be commenced but paused for up to eight years. Problematic, but not impossible. What does make the prosecution of Trump much more problematic is the fact that he enjoys enough popular support to make a prosecution more trouble than it's worth. However, that could easily change if and when Trump is impeached and resigns, or is removed from office

Yes, after he’s impeached and thrown out of office. Some on this answer think that the Vice President will pardon Trump, but I don’t believe he will. The reason. When Gerald Ford pardoned Richard Nixon, it was highly controversial. Some on both sides saw it as a backroom bargain between Nixon and Ford so that Ford could attain the presidency. It was felt that this was the main reason Ford lost the election to Jimmy Carter in 1976. From the Wikipedia article on Ford: The New York Times stated that the Nixon pardon was a "profoundly unwise, divisive and unjust act" that in a stroke had destroyed the new president's "credibility as a man of judgment, candor and competence". On October 17, 1974, Ford testified before Congress on the pardon. He was the first sitting President since Abraham Lincoln to testify before the House of Representatives. Ford would come to regret the decision, even though it may have been the correct one at the time. Again from Wikipedia: After Ford left the White House in January 1977, the former President privately justified his pardon of Nixon by carrying in his wallet a portion of the text of Burdick v. United States, a 1915 U.S. Supreme Court decision which stated that a pardon indicated a presumption of guilt, and that acceptance of a pardon was tantamount to a confession of that guilt. In 2001, the John F. Kennedy Library Foundation awarded the John F. Kennedy Profile in Courage Award to Ford for his pardon of Nixon. In presenting the award to Ford, Senator Edward Kennedy said that he had initially been opposed to the pardon of Nixon, but later decided that history had proved Ford to have made the correct decision. The reason why I’ve changed my tune on Nixon’s pardon (as an angry 14 year old, I felt Nixon should have rotted in a Federal prison in Alaska) is that we had gone through 18 months of turmoil as a nation. A Nixon trial would only have prolonged the pain even more. As far as Ford losing the election in 1976, AFAIC, the Democrats could have run Lancelot Link: Secret Chimp against Ford and he’d have won. Small point of usage here. People opining, prognosticating, or making predictions on this and currently related topics and individuals keep saying “will so-and-so go to jail.” The appropriate word is prison. Here in King County, state of Washington (for those who don't know, that's the county that Seattle is in; FWIW, King was a senator from Alabama, later vice president to Franklin Pierce, and possibly, although this is disputed by some historians, gay), jail is a holding facility before trials or for incarceration for less than 365 days, on local or state charges, generally of a less-serious nature than, among other possibilities “conspiracy against the United States,” sometimes referred to as “treason in peacetime” (the more-correct name for “collusion,” which was only a placeholder designation). Prison is where an individual is sent, after conviction, for longer sentences after conviction for state or federal. The distinction between jails and prisons and the uses the justice system makes of them are probably relatively consistent across jurisdictions. (OTOH, and in distinction to the prevalent but incorrect usage of many people currently, Paul Manafort is already in federal prison, only awaiting trial.) Ah, but back to DJT, beloved by some, reviled by others, and whether he'll go to prison. There are several imponderables here: (1) we don't know exactly what information the Special Counsel will eventually present and how damning it will be, but as the weeks pass the information seems more compelling, more damning; we'll see eventually what the SC has, (2) there is the question of whether a sitting president can be indicted and tried in a court of law; possibly not, but if he is impeached and convicted, or after his term ends anyway, he could be, certainly, (3) there is the issue of his age and health, and how long he will live. Related to his baseline, in addition to his probable poor health is the enormous stress he is likely experiencing, and its effect on his health and the remaining length of his life, and (4) there is the question of how much cash he or supporting parties can marshal to fund delaying legal efforts. Still, based on the likely results of the special investigation, including probable culpatory testimony from several individuals, as well as parallel state legal efforts in process, and if I was a betting person, I'd put money on DJT spending some time in prison.

Not during his presidency, and possibly not after it either. The only example we have is Richard Nixon, who committed crimes while in office and was never prosecuted for any of them. The Constitution provides a single solution for a President accused of crimes - impeachment by the House (the functional equivalent of a grand jury indictment, or official charge of wrongdoing) followed by a trial in the Senate. If found guilty by 2/3 of the Senate, the president is immediately removed from office and is then subject to the possibility of civil or criminal prosecution. We’ve had two presidents impeached - Andrew Johnson and Bill Clinton. Neither was found guilty by the Senate (Johnson escaping by a single vote). Neither was really subject to prosecution after leaving office because the accusations against them were politically motivated. In Nixon’s case, there were actual crimes committed. Articles of impeachment were being drawn up, and the Republican Senate leadership met with him to tell him that he would probably be convicted in the Senate on those charges. He chose to resign instead, which left him open to criminal prosecution once he was out of office, but he was almost immediately granted a full pardon by Gerald Ford. That is probably the same scenario that would play out for Trump if there is evidence of actual criminal behavior on his part. If he were to be impeached, convicted, and removed from office, he would undoubtedly be pardoned by Mike Pence and not subject to federal prosecution for those crimes. But… A presidential pardon only addresses federal crimes - it’s useless against state crimes. Some of the stuff that Trump and his cronies have been accused of fall under the jurisdiction of NY and the AG of that state is investigating. It is quite possible that he could be charged with a host of federal crimes and be pardoned without even seeing the inside of a federal courtroom, only to walk into a buzzsaw in NY. It’s also possible that he completes his one or two terms of office without any impeachment, but NY will still be waiting for him. If he goes to prison, it will likely be not because of what he did as Donald Trump, POTUS, it will be because of what he did as Donald Trump, a citizen of NY.

The president can be impeached, but impeachment is a political process not a criminal one. Criminal penalties or sentences cannot be levied by Congress. And federal lawyers in the Attorney General’s office have determined in the past that it's unconstitutional to indict a sitting president because it would keep the executive branch from performing its job. “An impeachment proceeding is the only appropriate way to deal with a president while in office,” Assistant Attorney General Robert Dixon explained in 1973 in the first opinion of the Justice Department’s Office of Legal Counsel. That doesn't mean presidents are above justice. Once they leave the White House, they can still face a criminal case over their actions before, during or after their stint in the Oval Office, and if found guilty then, yes, they could go to jail.
